proof.text: For let the two straight lines ,  meeting one another be parallel to the two straight lines ,  meeting one another, not being in the same plane; I say that the planes produced through ,  and ,  will not meet one another.
For let  be drawn from the point  perpendicular to the plane through ,  [elem.11.11], and let it meet the plane at the point ; through  let  be drawn parallel to , and  parallel to . [elem.1.31]
Now, since  is at right angles to the plane through , , therefore it will also make right angles with all the straight lines which meet it and are in the plane through , . [elem.11.def.3]
But each of the straight lines ,  meets it and is in the plane through , ; therefore each of the angles ,  is right.
And, since  is parallel to , [elem.11.9] therefore the angles ,  are equal to two right angles. [elem.1.29]
But the angle  is right; therefore the angle  is also right; therefore  is at right angles to .
For the same reason  is also at right angles to .
Since then the straight line  is set up at right angles to the two straight lines ,  which cut one another, therefore  is also at right angles to the plane through , . [elem.11.4]
But planes to which the same straight line is at right angles are parallel; [elem.11.14] therefore the plane through ,  is parallel to the plane through , .
Therefore, if two straight lines meeting one another be parallel to two straight lines meeting one another, not in the same plane, the planes through them are parallel. Q. E. D.
